docs.snippet: If contemporary Canadian and Latin-American music is still not widely enough known in the United States, it is not the fault of the Inter-American Music Festival. Since 1958, this organization has presented more than 300 world premieres and many more...
docs.lead_paragraph: If contemporary Canadian and Latin-American music is still not widely enough known in the United States, it is not the fault of the Inter-American Music Festival. Since 1958, this organization has presented more than 300 world premieres and many more first United States performances. At first, the festival was held every three years; in 1976, it became an annual event. On Monday night, a group from Chile (with the decidedly non- Latin name of Ensemble Bartok) opened the 1985 festival with a program of recent music by South American composers.

headline.main: CONCERT: FESTIVAL OF CANADIAN AND LATIN MUSIC

docs.snippet: Wisse Dekker, 60, the president and chairman of N.V. Philips, the Dutch electrical and electronics group, will step down as chief executive next April, the company said yesterday. The company said Mr. Dekker would be succeeded by the company's vice...
docs.lead_paragraph: Wisse Dekker, 60, the president and chairman of N.V. Philips, the Dutch electrical and electronics group, will step down as chief executive next April, the company said yesterday. The company said Mr. Dekker would be succeeded by the company's vice president and deputy chairman of the management board, Cor van der Klugt, 60.

headline.main: Top Executive Shift Planned at N.V. Philips

byline.original: By Kenneth N. Gilpin and Todd S. Purdum

docs.snippet: Chile's national soccer team has been fined $5,770 for spectator violence and ''poor stadium organization'' at a March 24 World Cup qualifying game against Uruguay in Santiago, the International Soccer Federation said today.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chile's national soccer team has been fined $5,770 for spectator violence and ''poor stadium organization'' at a March 24 World Cup qualifying game against Uruguay in Santiago, the International Soccer Federation said today.

docs.snippet: T he big news from Havana this spring, apparently unnoticed by the Nicaragua-obsessed Reagan Administration, is Cuba's rapid emergence from a quarter of a century of political and diplomatic isolation in Latin America.   Moreover, the United States,...
docs.lead_paragraph: T he big news from Havana this spring, apparently unnoticed by the Nicaragua-obsessed Reagan Administration, is Cuba's rapid emergence from a quarter of a century of political and diplomatic isolation in Latin America. Moreover, the United States, which had worked so hard all these years to keep the Cubans isolated, now finds itself increasingly alienated in the hemisphere because the Latin Americans are convinced that the Reagan White House does not care about their awesome economic crisis and Fidel Castro does. In historical terms, the shift in Latin American attitudes toward President Castro is vastly more important than, say, the Reagan's Administration's defeat in the Congress over funding of the Nicaraguan ''contras.'' However, one has the impression that the Administration does not even remotely understand this fact and its dangerous long-range impact on United States influence in the region.

byline.original: By Tad Szulc; Tad Szulc, a Washington-based writer, is working on a biography of Fidel Castro

docs.snippet: A festival that has so far been nearly as drab as the weather at this supposedly sunny seaside resort was briefly enlivened today when a middle-aged man threw a cake topped with shaving cream at the director who used to be the intellectual hero of...
docs.lead_paragraph: A festival that has so far been nearly as drab as the weather at this supposedly sunny seaside resort was briefly enlivened today when a middle-aged man threw a cake topped with shaving cream at the director who used to be the intellectual hero of the French film industry, Jean-Luc Godard. The cake-thrower, who was hustled away by security guards after the incident, identified himself only as ''George the whipped-cream-splatterer'' and ''the mutilator of icons.'' The cake, which hit Mr. Godard square in the face, was the third blow of the day for the director. First, Italian film distributors refused to withdraw his film ''Hail Mary'' after he asked them to do so. Then ''Detective,'' his new film about murder, marriage and the Mafia, was booed by the audience at a crowded early-morning press screening.

headline.main: GODARD HAS A BAD DAY IN CANNES...AND TRIES TO WITHDRAW 'HAIL MARY' IN ITALY

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: IN the realm of human evil, the figure of the torturer whose acts of brutality are carried out in the service of the state is a special puzzle.   The stereotype is that the torturer - a brutal police interrogator, for example - is driven by a warped...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the realm of human evil, the figure of the torturer whose acts of brutality are carried out in the service of the state is a special puzzle. The stereotype is that the torturer - a brutal police interrogator, for example - is driven by a warped sadism. But more commonly, some psychologists say, torturers are often not sadists so much as otherwise normal people who under certain circumstances sink into a routine of intimate horror in which they hurt or mutilate another human being, while staying aloof from the screams and agony of their victims. What circumstances can lead someone who may well consider himself a decent person to commit such inhumane acts, blind to the reality of the secret monster he has become? The puzzle takes on all the more urgency in New York now because of the recent allegations of torture made against a group of New York City police officers.

headline.main: THE TORTURER'S MIND: COMPLEX VIEW EMERGES

docs.snippet: After more than two decades of rejection and isolation, Fidel Castro is building new relationships in South America, dispelling many old suspicions and succeeding in dimming his image as a threatening revolutionary, many diplomats say.   In the last...
docs.lead_paragraph: After more than two decades of rejection and isolation, Fidel Castro is building new relationships in South America, dispelling many old suspicions and succeeding in dimming his image as a threatening revolutionary, many diplomats say. In the last year, Cuba has received a $600 million loan from Argentina. The right-of-center President of Ecuador, Leon Febres Cordero, made a formal visit to Cuba in April, and there have been signs that Uruguay, Peru and possibly Brazil may soon re-establish full diplomatic relations with Cuba. Cuba remains without diplomatic relations with Colombia, but Western diplomats and Cuban officials say that Mr. Castro has developed a personal relationship with President Belisario Betancur and that the two speak by telephone several times a week. In early May, Mr. Castro sent a shipment of medical supplies to Bolivia and 15 buses to Guyana. Both were gifts.

headline.main: CASTRO BUILDS RELATIONS WITH SOUTH AMERICA

byline.original: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: SUNDAY, MAY 19, 1985 International     Argentina froze all dollar accounts for 120 days in a move to stem the rapid increase of dollar withdrawals that began a week ago when the Government closed down the country's eighth largest bank. The freeze...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUNDAY, MAY 19, 1985 International Argentina froze all dollar accounts for 120 days in a move to stem the rapid increase of dollar withdrawals that began a week ago when the Government closed down the country's eighth largest bank. The freeze affects some $700 million to $1 billion in the banking system, banking sources said. [Page 1, Column 2.]

docs.snippet: Reagan Administration officials called on Latin American governments today to speed change in economic policies to attract more private capital as the way to guarantee future stability and ease the debt crisis.   David C. Mulford, Assistant Secretary...
docs.lead_paragraph: Reagan Administration officials called on Latin American governments today to speed change in economic policies to attract more private capital as the way to guarantee future stability and ease the debt crisis. David C. Mulford, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, warned at a daylong conference at the State Department that the region's capital needs would not be met either by more foreign aid or greater United States absorption of Latin exports. Without ''fundamental'' changes, the region faces a new debt ''storm,'' he told the Council of the Americas, a group of 150 business leaders from the Americas who meet in Washington for a day every year to discuss Western Hemisphere problems.

headline.main: U.S. BIDS LATIN NATIONS LURE PRIVATE CAPITAL

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A Paris-based Nazi hunter led a small demonstration here today to demand the arrest and extradition of the Auschwitz death-camp doctor, Josef Mengele, who she says is being protected by Paraguay's rightist regime.   The Nazi hunter, Beate Klarsfeld,...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Paris-based Nazi hunter led a small demonstration here today to demand the arrest and extradition of the Auschwitz death-camp doctor, Josef Mengele, who she says is being protected by Paraguay's rightist regime. The Nazi hunter, Beate Klarsfeld, who with her husband, Serge, played a key role in getting Klaus Barbie, the war criminal, extradited from Bolivia to France in 1983, said she was convinced that Dr. Mengele is in Paraguay. ''If you think logically, there is no where else that he could be,'' she said. ''If he left, the police must know, it must be in their files.''

headline.main: NAZI HUNTER, IN A PROTEST IN PARAGUAY, DEMANDS MENGELE'S ARREST

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times
